title: Will Senator Rob Portman (R-OH) be re-elected this November?
preds: *This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Also in line with consensus. And incumbents have a 98% chance of victory as well.
Sen. Portman continues  to lead by as many as 16 points. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
Portmans's >15 point lead insurmountable in 3 days
Seems to be coasting at this point.

Senator Portman has run a near-flawless campaign in a race that is completely overshadowed by the Presidential race in the State which has resulted in little energy to scrutinize the Senate candidates and create controversy.  In recent years, Ohio tends to support Republicans for statewide office.
High favorables for the incumbent and unwarranted (but effective) attacks of his opponent.

Ted Strickland - another career politician looking for additional pension benefits.   When he was the governor, he presented himself as an avid hunter and pro-2nd amendment.  What a difference being out of office makes.

Overwhelming support from republicans on both fronts: pro and anti Trump. Portman's reluctance to support Trump after that famous tape pleased one side, while Pence's urge for the current senator's re-election convinced the other. Ohio is a largely Republican state, with the electorate predominantly supporting the senator's voting record. I expect no surprises there.

This Oct. 18 article on Cleveland.com, http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/rob_portman_keeps_big_lead_in.html, indicates Portman has the election won. Raising my probability estimate to 100 percent Portman wins.
Most recent polls give Portman a clear advantage: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
It looks like some republicans might not vote this time

Moving down a little based on...
http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/10/things_are_looking_up_for_hill.html
Portman is so far ahead in the polls.

He's run an excellent campaign. Unlike Hillary, his flip flop on the TPP appears to have worked - he even has support of the big unions. The piece in today's WashPost indicates the Democratic party is near conceding at this point: "The Buckeye State was supposed to be ground zero in the battle for the Senate. Portman trailed in the polls as recently as this spring, but several handicappers have now taken the race off the map. National Democrats have canceled more than $7 million in Ohio advertising reservations, which has prompted GOP super PACs to follow suit. His surprising strength has increased the odds of the GOP holding onto its majority." http://link.washingtonpost.com/view/546d0c123b35d071228b77cf4nahm.5dof/7264fe76
Polls continue to move toward Portman, his lead is over 10% now in polling averages.  Hard to see him losing at this point.

According to this Oct. 4 Politico article, http://www.politico.com/story/2016/10/rob-portman-fundraising-ohio-strickland-229074, Portman continues to raise a robust amount of money to maintain his significant lead over Strickland. I'm increasing my probability estimate Portman will win.
Unless there is a sudden reversal of fortunes, the polls are pretty clear who is going to win.
DT reportedly riding Portman's support in OH.

Normally a Senate election, in a presidential election year, in the ultimate Middle American swing state would be a tossup. This year, though, Portman has gotten the support of some key unions (UMW, Teamsters, IUOE, Fraternal Order of Police) that limit Ted Strickland's ability to mobilize union support. Combine that with Trump's general white working class appeal, which seems to be having more of an impact in Ohio than in neighboring Michigan and Pennsylvania, and Portman has the advantage.

Incumbency and polling are both good reasons to suspect he will win.
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate
This is a very smart guy who has run a very smart campaign against a very smart opponent.  Hair Boy will lose Ohio, but ticket-splitting will save Portman.
Portman's got this in the bag http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html

Consensus is at 85% and PredictWise agrees, I don't know what Portman has done but it has improved his chances considerably.

Portman's polling just keeps getting better and better.
Latest poll shows he is way ahead, here is link to Cleveland source http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/donald_trump_extends_lead_over.html#incart_2box
Strickland had the lead until the summer. Wonder what happened there. Now Portman consistently polling better.

According to this Sept. 11 article in Washington Post, https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/thanks-to-rubio-and-portman-retaining-senate-majority-remains-within-gop-reach/2016/09/11/0dd0d0a2-7830-11e6-a482-61b767c17607_story.html, Portman is comfortably ahead, according to polls. I'm increasing my probability estimate Portman will win in my home state.

 Ohio – Republican incumbent Rob Portman buries former Gov. Ted Strickland, his
Democratic challenger, 51 – 40 percent. Quinnipiac university poll
The D money is going elsewhere.  Since Clinton will carry Ohio, Rob will need ticket-splitting, but will likely get it.

http://www.ohio.com/news/politics/state/political-ad-buys-in-ohio-cancelled-as-outside-groups-see-portman-pulling-ahead-1.709272 ". . . national Democrats signaled even less confidence in the race as the Senate Majority PAC and the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, or DSCC, canceled another round of ads set to air Sept. 13. However, help is on the way for Strickland in the form of U.S. senators Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bernie Sanders of Vermont. Warren will attend a Sept. 17 fundraiser in Cleveland on behalf of Strickland, according to media reports. And Sanders asked his supporters to donate $2.70 each to Strickland and three other Democratic Senate candidates.
. . . 
" . . . Portman’s campaign, with thousands of volunteers and $10 million more in cash than Strickland’s, has claimed to have touched 3.5 million voters, or about 62 percent of the 5.6 million who voted in 2012  . . .

This Aug. 30 article in the Columbus Dispatch notes that both Repubs and Dems have pulled back on ad spending because it looks like Portman has the race wrapped up ... http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/08/30/democratic-group-begins-canceling-ads-supporting-ted-strickland.html. +10 from 61
In two U.S. Senate races, the Republican incumbents seem likely to hold on to their seats. Ohio’s Rob Portman
has a wide lead over former Democratic Governor Ted Strickland (40% to 25%), although 25% of Ohio voters
remain undecided. Portman is viewed much more positively (41% favorable, 35% unfavorable) than Strickland
(26% favorable, 54% unfavorable). In Pennsylvania, incumbent GOP Senator Pat Toomey holds a 7-point lead
(46% to 39%) over Democratic challenger Katie McGinty, with 10% of voters undecided. "
Cleveland Plain Dealer all but admits Strickland is "toast"... http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/09/is_it_too_late_for_ted_strickl.html#incart_river_home
Continuing lead in the polls and higher campaign money increases his odds.
Portman still increasing lead in polls, last at +15%

Ohioans split rather a lot compared to others but he could still get swept away, depending on how Hillary does.  I will be jittery about this one until election night, probably.  On the bright side, either of these lads would be an excellent Senator; this is not usual.

Another 4% say they will vote for another candidate and 8% are undecided.  Portman garners more support from his fellow Republicans (88%) than Strickland does from his fellow Democrats (76%).  Independents prefer Portman by 47% to 37%.

“Every trade deal we make stinks” because “we don’t have smart people making the deals,” Trump’s is heard saying in the Strickland ad, which attacks Portman’s performance as Bush’s trade negotiator.
. . ..
". . . it’s unclear how effective Strickland’s tactics have been. A Quinnipiac University poll released July 14 showed Portman ahead by 7 percentage points, though an NBC/Wall Street Journal poll released July 13 said the race was a dead heat. "As trade representative, Portman helped push the Central American Free Trade Agreement through Congress . . . . After the vote, Portman  . . . jousted with Chinese trade officials over software and movie piracy and textile exports, which the Commerce Department limited because of market disruption. In the Senate, Portman teamed up with Democrats . . . to push legislation to impose sanctions for China’s currency manipulation. . . . Portman’s record as a supporter of free-trade deals during his 14 years in the House, where one of his earliest votes was to approve the North American Free Trade Agreement . . .  If Trump’s anti-free trade rhetoric isn’t awkward enough for Portman, the party’s split in Ohio is an additional complication. Kasich, an unsuccessful candidate for the Republican presidential nomination, boycotted this week’s convention while refusing to back Trump.
. . .
"The decision by Kasich, the titular head of the Ohio Republican Party, to sit out the presidential election campaign, may pose another problem for Portman: turning out the party faithful at the polls in November. . . .  “If the presidential candidate is unpopular, it’s a challenge” for down-ballot candidates to motivate party activists “to come out” and support get-out-the-vote efforts . . . " . . . the Portman campaign operation can’t compete with the unified Democratic campaign for presumptive presidential nominee Hillary Clinton and all other party candidates running statewide in Ohio. “All the Democratic field efforts are done through the Ohio Democratic Party, which is the Clinton campaign, the Strickland campaign,”  [However, Portman's] done an amazing job with volunteers." Portman “is running about the best grassroots campaign Ohio has seen,”  "One advantage for Portman is that he’s popular among Republican regulars,  . .  . “The party activists really love the guy." "Johnson [chairman of the Columbiana County Republican Party] said pollsters are underestimating Republican enthusiasm for Trump in an economically challenged state like Ohio. And with polls showing a tight presidential race in Ohio, traditionally a swing state, turnout for Trump should help Portman among Republican voters, [Former Ohio Republican Representative ] Pryce said. “If Trump gets the Republicans out, I don’t know why they wouldn’t vote for Senator Portman.”

Portman seems to be motivated to run an assertive campaign in light of the close race in my home state of Ohio. This July 16 Associated Press article on the Washington Post website gives some insight on how the Portman team is approaching Ohio voters: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/portmans-ohio-campaign-a-sharp-contrast-to-trumps/2016/07/16/35b442c4-4b4f-11e6-8dac-0c6e4accc5b1_story.html I'm slightly raising my probability estimate that Portman could win in November.
Trump campaign disarray will extend down ballot and make Portman a loser.

I'm going to slightly up my prediction for Portman based on a couple of reasons:
1) New poll showing him ahead (as well as other polls showing Ohio tightening nationally) (http://www.qu.edu/news-and-events/quinnipiac-university-poll/2016-presidential-swing-state-polls/release-detail?ReleaseID=2366). Now the poll has Portman up 7 which is a big jump from any other polling, there's likely a lot of noise in that poll. BUT I do think there's reason to believe Portman is at least a few point ahead. 2) That combined with Portman's growing fundraising lead (http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/portman-ohio-senate-strickland-225140?platform=hootsuite) gives me reason to slightly boost Portman.

The race between Portman and former Ohio governor Ted Strickland is apparently still a toss-up -- but Portman is worried. How will the influence of Trump and Clinton affect the race? Here's Politico article that provides some insight (with a focus on John Kasich's role): http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/john-kasich-rob-portman-ohio-224941 I'm slightly raising my probability estimate that Portman could win, but I'm still favoring Strickland just a bit.
Portman has pulled ahead very slightly, but too close to call.
Portman is moving up some in the polls.  Still early, though.   A fun election, because both of these lads are pretty good.  This is not, shall we say, universally the case.  A lucky year for Ohio.

Ohio Senator Rob Portman is in a close battle with former Governor Ted Strickland. Ohio is a traditional swing state with President Obama taking the popular vote in the last 2 elections (2008, 2012), while current Governor John Kasich beat Strickland in 2010 and Rob Portman took his seat in the same cycle.  This would typically be considered a close election with Portman having a slight edge due to his incumbency (http://www.andreamoro.net/perm/papers/why_do_incumbent_senators_win.pdf) and that this election cycle would typically be seen as advantageous to Republicans (8 years of Democratic White House control and an average economic situation.  I will look at a few key variables in assessing this race: polling, fundraising/general campaign quality, candidate quality and potential coattails. These are not the only important variables but will serve as a good starting point. It is also important to realise that these variables are not equally valuable ie. Being ahead in the polls is more valuable than having more money in the bank. The key thing to remember here is that there is a long way to go until the election, that time period means there is significant uncertainty in any prediction; for this reason frequent updating and responding to new information is the best way to accurately gauge the result.  It’s important to set a base level for our prediction. I generally think the betting/prediction markets are useful for setting this base but there is bit of a discrepancy on this particular race. PredictIt has the likelihood of Portman winning at around 44% (https://www.predictit.org/Market/1321/Which-party-will-win-the-US-Senate-race-in-Ohio-in-2016) while Predictwise, on their market prediction, has the odds at around 45% (http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate). However PredictWise’s overall prediction is 56% (when considering fundamentals and polling). I will average those to reach a base of 51% likelihood for Portman (this is also in line with the Cook Report and Sabato describing the race as a toss-up).  Polling:
The Huffington Post poll-tracker has Portman with a slight (2.5%) lead (http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-senate-portman-vs-strickland). The last three polls have all shown Portman ahead or tied (all polls conducted in June). In general this would be considered a good but not great position for an incumbent (compare to Ron Johnson being 10 points down in a similar race in Wisconsin). There are two issues with this lead. Firstly we are too far from the election for such a small lead to be hugely significant (this is the equivalent of being up a field goal at half time). The polling also has a large amount of undecided (nearly 20% in the most recent poll). It’s possible to make arguments that these undecideds help or hurt Portman; I’m not fully convinced by either so will call it a wash. 
Overall: It’s generally better to be up 2% at this point that not and as the incumbent that advantage is probably even more so. I’ll boost Portman up to 55% on this evidence and will continue to boost him if the lead holds over the next few months. Portman 55% Fundraising/Campaign quality:
Portman has, and continues to have a large lead in money on hand. (http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2016/04/rob_portman_continues_fundrais.html). I’m generally ambivalent on the importance of money on hand but this seems like a fairly clear advantage. In general the two campaigns seem fairly evenly-matched in other areas.
Overall: I’ll boost Portman 2% with additional boosts if his large lead in campaign money continues. Portman 57% Candidate quality:
I think, in general, this issue only matters if one candidate is clearly a negative or huge positive. In this case there is evidence that Portman may be unusually weak as an incumbent with very low name recognition (http://www.dispatch.com/content/stories/local/2016/05/11/portman-strickland-senate-ohio-poll.html). However Strickland is also potentially weak with lots of voters knowing him and not liking him (based on his time as governor). I think this is basically a wash for now with the potential for movement if one candidate successfully weakens the other on a particular issue.
Overall: No change Coattails:
This elephant in the room for predicting this, and indeed any race this cycle, is Donald Trump. The conventional wisdom is that Trump will damage generic Republican chances down-ballot due to his unpopularity and potential to bring out an unusually large Democratic turnout. I’m open to this theory (although the evidence for a large coattails effect is limited), but it is also quite hard to quantify. There is little evidence that Trump is currently damaging Portman; Portman has gained in the polls during the last month while Trump’s favourable have been going down. Until more data and information emerges I don’t think we can consider Trump to be inherently damaging, however I do think he creates further uncertainty (ie. the chance of Trump damaging Portman is higher than the chance of him helping and that chance lowers Portman’s odds). 
Overall: I’ll knock Portman down to 54% due to the uncertainty (in a generic election year I’d likely lift him a little). Again we need more information here before we can have much certainty. Overall I think there’s reason to have Portman as the slight favourite, while clearly recognising there are two big uncertainties (time and Trump). The status quo clearly favours Portman so without significant change I will likely slowly lift Portman’s odds while changes in either way will result in corresponding odds changes.  Portman: 54%

Leaving my prediction at 50%, but changing methodology.  Since predicting should be a team sport, here are my thoughts. I believe that there really are three things that are important predicting elections.   Where are we, where are we going, and how sure we are about our prediction. The best way to figure out where we are, imho, is polls.  That's actually the place to start.  We are at 50/50. Where we are going is based upon the candidate's head wind or tail wind.  What is the environment he/she is playing with?  This includes national party unity or chaos, the leaning of the underlying state, how good of a politician this candidate and his/her opponent is, how deep of pockets both have, whether there is a ceiling to their support, and whether said candidate or opponent is an incumbent. How sure we are should start at not very sure, but become more sure over time.  6 months out, there is plenty of fog of war.  2 days from the election, there may be much less confusion (it's the polls, stupid).  Start closer to 50/50 (even if there is reason to believe otherwise), move towards yes or no over time. In other words, what are the odds, and what are the error bands? OK, what are the numbers? Polls = about even, 50%
Incumbent advantage = 30% 
    Although most incumbents win, how about those that are tied?  There has to be some advantage, maybe 30% out 6 months?  
      This will shrink over time, as polls reflect reality.
Republican turmoil = - 30%  
    Remaining the same. Things are starting to look more like Trump, but on the other hand, we are going to have Trump.  
    If we don't get trump, we get lots of turmoil.  So, turmoil is baked in. Other senator democrat = -5%
Ohio house 14 more republicans = 5%
  How friendly is the state to Republicans? = 50% What are the error bands?  Big.  Lets stay at 50%. I expect, over time, to rely more on polls, and less on guesses.

To Portman's  advantage is the recent announcement by a major US automaker that they are plowing $1.3 billion into an existing  auto plan in Northern Ohio. http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/22/us/politics/with-uncertainty-at-top-of-ticket-republicans-back-off-in-some-states.html?emc=edit_th_20160422&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=28699183 "The Republican National Committee is scaling back its financial commitments to some of the most hotly contested states because of flagging fund-raising . . .  the committee’s chief strategist, acknowledged this week that the committee had begun informing state parties and statewide campaigns that fulfilling such plans [to provide field organizers]  would now be “slower.” . . . 
"Just as revealing, the party is also taking steps to create a separate fund-raising entity dedicated to Senate races, an acknowledgment that many of the wealthiest contributors are increasingly focused on protecting Republican control of Congress rather than on a presidential campaign they fear is lost.
. . . 
“I think everything is up in the air,” said Matt Borges, the chairman of the Republican Party in Ohio, which in addition to being a perennial, and perhaps the pre-eminent, swing state is also home to a competitive Senate race this year.
. . . 
" . . .  worrisome to many veteran Republicans . . .  is what his [Trump's] nomination could mean for the party’s prospects across the board this fall. Mr. Trump has no high-dollar donor network and has given little indication that he is willing to tap into his fortune to give the party the hundreds of millions of dollars it will require to finance its campaigns in the fall.
. . .
"In the 2012 elections, the R.N.C. raised more than $409 million. The party has raised $135 million this election, but what is deeply concerning to many Republican candidates, contributors and strategists is that it only had a little more than $16 million on hand, along with nearly $2 million in debt, at the end of March. Mr. Spicer stressed that this was partly because the committee had already begun paying to send staff members to battleground states, well ahead of the same time four years ago. "But the party’s modest cash availability underscores how much hangs in the balance with its nominee. The minute Trump gets the nomination, the party is going to have to raise another three or four hundred million,” said Al Hoffman, a Florida-based Republican donor. . . .  Mr. Hoffman, a former R.N.C. finance chairman, . . .  said he had little appetite to raise money for a Trump-led party and would probably focus his efforts this year on helping a local House candidate and assisting the re-election of his friend, Senator John McCain of Arizona. And he emphasized that he was not alone. “All the donors I’ve talked to have said they want to sit out the presidential and just focus on the Senate and House,” Mr. Hoffman said. "Ray Washburne, a Republican fund-raiser from Dallas who also previously served as a national committee finance chairman, said, “There’s a big switch to doing the Senate races and trying to hold onto the Senate.” "Mr. Washburne said Mr. Trump, who has relied on mostly small-dollar contributors in addition to about $36 million of his own money, showed no sign of being prepared for the fund-raising demands of a presidential general election. “The Trump group has done nothing about putting together a finance team at all,” he said.  . . .  even as donors have asked him . . . how they could help Mr. Trump. “I don’t even know who the hell to tell them to call,” Mr. Washburne said. "This sort of unease about Mr. Trump, along with the dislike many of the party’s business-oriented donors have for the hard-line Mr. Cruz, has prompted the R.N.C. to begin privately assuring donors that it will create a so-called Senate Trust fund. Money earmarked for that fund will go entirely to initiatives aimed at retaining the Senate — including hiring field operatives and opposition researchers and bolstering digital efforts. . . . 
. . . 
“The unspoken concern,” said Mr. Borges, the Ohio chairman, is that if Mr. Trump secures the nomination, “he, No. 1, won’t participate in fund-raising for the party, and, No. 2, donors won’t want to help the party if he’s the nominee.”  “So that would put a real damper on fund-raising in a number of ways.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  The shift in focus in the RNC to fundraising for Senate races could make a difference in this race.  Increasing my forecast for Portman's re-election from 74 to 77%

Giving Portman the advantage for now.  Ohio has historically elected the same candidate multiple times, sometimes preferring the GOP, sometimes the Dems. Currently, Portman (R) and Sherrod Brown (D) have the two seats from Ohio.  Portman reportedly collected 9 times the contributions of his opponent in 2010, and has another large lead (13 to 2) in this election cycle.  He had a strong lead in 2016 primary votes, as the GOP pulled more voters than the Dems.  One negative is that the GOP has not won a Senate seat in a year the Dems won the presidency (going back to 1976): 1976 (49.5%),1992 (51%) and 2012 (50.7%), although the winning margins were fairly small. Another may be a fall off in voter turnout for the GOP, once the final candidate is known.  A positive for Porman : Strickland has asked for 5 debates, but, Portman is a GOP favorite in preping candidates in mock debates against upcoming opponents.   Both of Ohio's US Senators represent the entire state: Ohio's voting record in the second seat should also be relevant, as everyone votes for both Senators.
https://www.govtrack.us/congress/members/OH Between 1974 an 1992 the Dems won all 7 Senate races. Howard Metzenbaum won three and John Glenn won four with 64.6, 68.8, 62.5 and 51% in 1992, perhaps an indication of future elections.  These wins included 2 years where Dems won the presidency: 1976 and 1992, and 2 years where the GOP won the presidency: 1980 and 1988.
Between 1994 and 2004 the GOP won all 4 Senate races with vote percentages ranging from 53.4 to 64%, including 2 presidential election, both won by the GOP in 2000 and 2004.
Between 2006 and 2015, the Dems Sherrod Brown has won 2006 (56.2%) and 2012 (50.7%) while Portman(R) won with 57.3% in 2010.   In the Ohio primaries, Portman seemed to have the advantage; collecting 1,108,234 GOP votes (out of 1,598,696), compared with Strickland's 65% (720,336 of 1,108,234).
https://ballotpedia.org/United_States_Senate_election_in_Ohio,_2016

As I go through all these GJ questions I ask myself further questions to better understand the subject.  At times I do not post them all because they may be considered “way out there”.   But here is a question I asked myself about the elections this year...  Is it better to be a democrat trying to be more conservative or a republican trying to be more liberal?  I am leaning towards a republican with liberal social views at present.  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/208704  We can't ignore social mood. Additional Senator Portman re-election info...  I have lived all over the US to include Ohio.  Cincinnati 2013-2015.  I actually met Senator Portman in Cincinnati when he visited our unit he seems like a straightforward and genuine guy.  A part of my family tree lives in northern Ohio many are union or former union.  Most of my grandparents neighbors are all union.  Retired truck drivers, masons, builders, forklift operators, you name it.  Senator Portman has a reasonable chance to save Ohio union pensions. I'm also forecasting Portman will meet with meet with Judge Garland.    (Edit) "since he voted for Loretta Lynch for US AG" Many Ohioans remember the debt Ted Strickland left the state in during his time as Governor.  They also remember that he brought the casinos in which were supposed to “fix” the debt issues.  To date the casinos have not performed as forecasted by the Strickland administration.  Strickland also has the reputation of “trying to give everyone what they want which led to Ohio debt issues and his failed re-election bid against Kasich”. “The only thing that could sabotage his re-election would be a financial scandal”

This one is a very tough call.  Ohio is a very close swing state, and if turnout from Democrats is high, as would be expected with Trump or Cruz as the Republican presidential nominee, it would seem that the Democrats would have a slight advantage.  That said, Portman has some advantage as an incumbent, his approval ratings have been decent, though not great, and he has been very effective at raising money, which may be an indication of strength as a candidate.  I give Portman the slight edge at this point as the incumbent.

Strickland was Governor of Ohio and has a few things he will have to defend for example gun control, school vouchers, and abortion.  Strickland seems more like a blue-dog democrat.  On the other hand Portman the incumbent senator is popular in Ohio he won all but 4 or five counties from the previous campaign.  Portman was recently thanked by the Ohio steel workers for protecting the industry from from foreign influence.  Portman is now fighting to protect over 45K union pensions at the federal level.  This is the story I will be following closely.  Will Portman be able to save these pensions from cuts?  I think he will considering his former federal government positions.   On a side note Strickland is tweeting about how Portman will not vote for a Supreme Court Justice...although important he is missing the mark on what buckeyes think is important.  the two main issues are; jobs/pensions and heroin epidemic.  Whoever can successfully address these two issues will win.   https://www.ohiobar.org/NewsAndPublications/OhioLawyer/Pages/Fighting-Ohios-heroin-epidemic.aspx
http://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/brown-urges-treasury-department-to-protect-the-earned-benefits-of-thousands-of-ohioans-with-central-states-pension-plans
http://www.portman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?ID=D6E4A1CE-9C6B-4664-9758-7DEDB895142D

Per huffpo it's 75%, which takes into account number of polls and recency of polling to create probability of an actual lead: http://elections.huffingtonpost.com/pollster/2016-ohio-senate-portman-vs-strickland In reality, this is close to a true toss up. More polling is needed to get an idea of current preference, and the presidential election will change a lot. Will be updating with more polls and clearer presidential picture.
Predictit market is 58% for the Democrat.

This will be better answered once the presidential and vice presidential nominees are known.  If the Ohio governor is part of the Republican ticket then Portman is in otherwise it might be a at best a 50/50 chance.

Portman is quite a lot less crazy than the general run of his R colleagues, but it's probably going to be a D year in the swing states (also, by the way, in the bebop and r&b states).  I'll need to check with my Ohio people, but for the moment 47% feels good.  Probably not to Rob, though.

More research will be done (by me) to refine my forecast, but for now I am going to start at 45%, this seems to be a democratic year, and I believe Ohio is going to be more firmly in the D electoral vote column, and that means a Strickland win here makes the most sense.
Initial @Khalid Who the presidential nominees are and turnout should be key. Guessing it will be high if DT, perhaps in DT's favor.
per @Khalid, going a bit lower due to my current views on the Presidential race
Governors are seen as slightly less loathsome than those who politic in D.C.

Predictwise http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-congress-senate#Link3 gives the Democrats a 46% chance of winning, whereas Predictit's market https://www.predictit.org/Browse/Group/54/Congress gives Portman 42%. This looks like it may end up as a cliff-hanger and will definitely depend on how the Presidential race turns out.  The most recent poll, from early March, has Strickland ahead by 41-40 with a 2.8% margin of error. http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/senate/oh/ohio_senate_portman_vs_strickland-5386.html
The polls are close, but Portman is a strong candidate and I think he'll win.
Top-of-ticket forces seem likely to drag down Portman, but his cash advantage gives him a fighting chance.

Strickland has a very mixed electoral  record in Ohio. I don't know enough about him to say why. I'll stick with the polls that have him a little ahead, essentially a toss-up.  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Ohio,_2016
